title: 103_s1013
content: The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" is cited in this section, which amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It addresses the estate tax treatment of land under a qualified conservation easement. The "Rural Land Conservation Act of 1993" amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to address the estate tax treatment of land subject to a qualified conservation easement. If the executor elects, the value of such land (minus any debt) can be excluded from the gross estate. A qualified conservation easement is land located near a metropolitan area or national park, owned by the decedent or their family for at least 3 years before death, and subject to a qualified conservation contribution. The decedent's death must be related to a qualified conservation contribution of a qualified real property interest made by the decedent or a family member. Certain contributions are excluded, and the term "family member" is defined. If the donor retained any development right, a tax on disposition may apply. If the donor retained any development right when the qualified conservation contribution was made, an additional estate tax is imposed on the first person disposing of the property after the decedent's death. The amount of the additional tax is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been included in the gross estate. The additional estate tax is imposed on the person disposing of the property if a development right was retained during a qualified conservation contribution. The tax amount is based on the increase in estate tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been included in the gross estate. The tax is due by April 15 of the following year after the disposition. The term 'development right' refers to the right to establish structures for commercial purposes or engage in activities like farming on land subject to a qualified conservation easement. The election for this tax provision must be made on the estate tax return by April 15 of the following year after the disposition. The election for the tax provision regarding land subject to a qualified conservation easement must be made on the estate tax return by April 15 of the following year after the disposition. The executor making the election must compute the additional estate tax and file a 'Notice of Potential Estate Tax Due' in the locality where the land is located. The amendments made by this section apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, including land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after that date. The computation and filing required shall be done as prescribed by the Secretary. Gift tax on land with a qualified conservation easement. Gift Tax With Respect to Land Subject to a Qualified Conservation Easement: An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 introduces a provision where the transfer of land with a qualified conservation easement may not be considered a taxable gift. If the donor retains any development rights, an additional gift tax is imposed. If the donor retains any development right when making a gift of land subject to a qualified conservation easement, an additional gift tax is imposed on the first person disposing of the property after the gift. The tax amount is equal to the increase in gift tax liability that would have occurred if the value of the development right had been treated as a gift. The amendments made by this section apply to gifts of land subject to qualified conservation easements granted after December 31, 1992. SEC. 4 amends the special rule for qualified conservation contributions where surface and mineral rights are separated. It states that if the probability of surface mining on the property is remote, the contribution qualifies. The amendment applies to contributions made after December 31, 1992. SEC. 5 clarifies that a qualified conservation contribution is not considered a disposition. The amendment clarifies that a qualified conservation contribution by gift or otherwise is not considered a disposition for tax purposes. Additionally, land subject to a qualified conservation easement is not disqualified as qualified real property. The amendment clarifies that land subject to a qualified conservation easement is not disqualified as qualified real property for tax purposes. The amendments apply to estates of decedents dying after December 31, 1992, with qualified conservation easements granted after the same date.
